Questions.Question: Who said the famous quote 'To be, or not to be: that is the question'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is from William Shakespeare's play 'Hamlet', spoken by the character Hamlet.

Questions.Question: Which author wrote the quote 'It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is the opening line of Jane Austen's novel 'Pride and Prejudice'.

Questions.Question: Who said the famous quote 'It does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is from J.K. Rowling's book 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'.

Questions.Question: Which author wrote the quote 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is the opening line of Charles Dickens' novel 'A Tale of Two Cities'.

Questions.Question: Who said the famous quote 'All that is gold does not glitter'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is from J.R.R. Tolkien's book 'The Lord of the Rings'.

Questions.Question: Which author wrote the quote 'It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a zombie in possession of brains, must be in want of more brains'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is a parody of Jane Austen's quote and is from Seth Grahame-Smith's book 'Pride and Prejudice and Zombies'.

Questions.Question: Who said the famous quote 'It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is from William Shakespeare's play 'Macbeth', spoken by the character Macbeth.

Questions.Question: Which author wrote the quote 'It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single woman in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a husband'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is a parody of Jane Austen's quote and is from Helen Fielding's book 'Bridget Jones's Diary'.

Questions.Question: Who said the famous quote 'It was the best of times, it was the blurst of times'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote is a parody of Charles Dickens' quote and is from the TV show 'The Simpsons'.
